results.content:
I'm sad to report that I didn't find this very useful for practical application. I thought it was good at first but then tried to implement some of the learnings and found out that they don't work. 

Copy / pasting code is not really teaching anything other than to copy paste code. Time would have been better spent understanding why things work the way they do.

I think you may be better off using a template from mail chimp or campaign monitor and troubleshooting it with a testing tool like email on acid or litmus. 

There is no accommodation for the fact that Outlook has horrible rendering capabilities and needs to have specific work arounds. That's kind of important.

results.content:
The content is very dated in this course, all email clients he is using are pre 2014. Most of the information found in this  course can be found free on youtube. 

The first hour of the course is just him copy pasting things and typing CSS without explaining anything, he just says what he is doing. The only good content is probably the last 30mins where he actually breaks down some of the details and gives tips on designs.

For 10 bucks, it's ok if you just want an overview on how responsive emails look and are made. I'd also recommend just watching and not coding along cause you aren't learning anything with all the copy pasting and it will make the course take 3x as long.

Overall: Id pass on this an watch a free video on youtube to learn table tags.

results.content:
I really enjoyed this short course on creating responsive HTML emails because it hit all the necessary points without going into too much detail about rudimentary HTML and CSS. The fact that it's such a short course makes it so that you can go back and treat the entire series as a quick-reference case study if you're just learning HTML and CSS. I recently completed a few HTML and CSS courses through Udemy and that's as much as I know about markup so this course is perfect because it allows me to test the new skills I learned.

I plan to go back and review the semantics and styles that Chris used. Like I mentioned, he doesn't go into every little detail about why he added this much padding here or that much margin there, so it engages the student to have to review the course materials and think critically about the instructor's design choices. This in turn will help any user create their own designs and implementation.

If there was anything I would change, I suggest a bonus lecture on how to place a link that would open up the email in a web browser in case the end user can't render the full design. Should that link to a web page or a pdf file, etc.?

But other than that, I say take this course, I highly recommend it.

Happy coding!

results.content:
If, like me, you've been designing & coding static emails for a some time,  want to move to responsive email design, but have no idea how, then this course is for you! 
Chris is a great instructor. The pace of the course is great and easy to follow. A big plus : Chris also has a very agreeable voice! 
All the mark-up in the course files is clear, well-structured, and well-commented - great for ulterior reference. I specifically appreciated the extra explanations & tips at the end of the course ( lecture 33 ) to help with future designs & problems that may arise with various email clients.
Most importantly, at the end of this course, which took me roughly 4 hours to complete at a leisurely speed, I now know EXACTLY what to do to make my email designs responsive and how to test them.  All in all, a great, well-rounded course!
I look forward to taking the next Chris Converse course!

results.content:
There is no doubt that Chris Converse knows what he's talking about. With that, I think he goes a bit too fast for people that may not understand some of the CSS and HTML that is involved in this course. Perhaps informing potential students that they have a basic understanding of HTML and CSS before taking this class would have been beneficial. I'm also seeing questions that students have asked go unanswered for several days. I'm sure he's a very busy person, but it looks bad and leaves students questions unresolved.

Other than that, the course was very well put together and walks you step by step in the process. As an email developer myself, I found the course to be very informative and there were some pretty useful techniques.

results.content: I have some experience doing HTML and CSS for web development, but I haven't done anything with emails before, so I wanted an intro course. This one was really useful, but it would have been helpful for me to see the current state in the browser more often. I think I'll go back and code along with the videos so I can see what happens with each update. I think this is a good course for people with some coding background who want to get into email development. If you don't know any HTML and CSS you'll still be able to follow along and get the completed project, but it might be confusing. And if you're the kind of person who wants to know why each thing is necessary then this might not be the right course for you, since there's a lot of copying and pasting of blocks of code without much information on what it's doing.

results.content: Unfortunately the course has not been updated since 2017 - for instance, Gmail does now support responsiveness, apparently. The course is great but could really benefit from being updated to take into account new developments. For instance, when I validate my inline code, I get errors for most of the code for the embedded video section - the tutorial only shows that alt tag errors have been picked up for the icons, and no other errors. Without being an HTML & CSS developer (I'm a designer), I'm guessing these other errors are showing up because the doctype rules may have changed since 2017? I would love for the author to add a few videos highlighting changes that may have happened since the release of this course - It would get a higher rating if it was more current.

results.content:
Before taking this course I suggest you have a good grasp of knowledge in HTML5, CSS3 and Media Queries. 

As mentioned, this is an outdated course, and it's extremely fast paced. I had to pause the video numerous times just to catch up while he added styling elements. However, given that I'm quick with my typing and I have a good understanding of HTML and CSS, I enjoyed being challenged by typing out his commands as he stated them. This gave me the chance to actively listen. More importantly, after each section of rapidly typing the style elements, I enjoyed going back to the section and see whether I got a syntax error which was a great indicator of accuracy. On top of that, I recommend pausing the video on each of the section just so you can fiddle with the styling commands and media queries that he's adding to the HTML. Doing this made me realize the WHYs and HOWs and the OHs of his thinking behind things.

Overall, this is a good quick guide to your first Email markup and worth the $10 bucks if you're curious on this field. Otherwise, I've found other sites with more in-depth curiculum in the subject, but a bit more pricier.

results.content:
This is exactly what I expected when I saw the video preview for the course. Please keep in mind that this is not a beginner course. I took this course because I am studying front end development, so I already have an understanding of HTML, CSS and responsive design for web pages in general. 

Someone mentioned previously that you need to have Photoshop to take this course, that is not completely true. The project files included in this course are already sized & cut to the dimensions for this particular design example, so you can simply just follow along the video and code with the instructor. 

He included the PSD files for Photoshop, in case you wanted to see how he made the images. 

Please keep in mind that if you want to be a front end developer, responsive email design is one of many areas of front end design required to work with a company or even freelance, although you don't have to know how to use Photoshop or design a layout, it's useful to take a few courses on using them as well. 

I will admit that this material and the program he uses to code is a bit old, but, I did actually manage to understand how to make a responsive email with my own code editor and he did provide useful tips for responsive layout design using several <tables>. 

And he also did provide some useful resources for tips as well. Pretty good course.
